author: dizzlerama
content: Count me in.... I am interested in the Core Developer Apprenticeship Program...sent in my application today...it‚Äôs great to be here

author: pothos0019
content: Put of curiosity, do you guys have degrees? I've been having a hard time deciding on taking my chance at some bootcamps or going back to school

author: pipermerriam
content: I have a math degree.  I'm sure it's helped me a bit, but there's very little from university that I'd say applies directly to the work I do.  I know there are at least a few core devs without college degrees.  I don't think Vitalik has a degree...  Certainly not a requirement to do the work.

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: I think most of the core devs do have degrees in cs (at least B.Sc). I would recommend it as you'll run into a lot more problems with datastructures, low level stuff etc.  than in other jobs. That said, there are a lot of great devs that decided to quit uni to work on eth

author: pipermerriam
content: Yes, the CS knowledge is something that I've backfilled during my career and there's valuable stuff there, but a CS degree isn't going to teach you what you need to do core dev.  I think you'd be better off studying CS concepts on the side while directly learning about the actual protocols themselves.

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: Agreed! Alas for me, having a CS background helped me understand the protocols and some of the tradeoffs that were made

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: If you're here already, I wouldn't recommend you to go back to uni though^^

author: pothos0019
content: I very fresh to programming in general, did some slight self learning. As of now I'm in a free course offered by Stanford called Code In Place, but its focus is revolving around Python. I'd like to transition my learning experience that best suits Ethereum's languages, if not uni whould a bootcamp in Js be useful? Thank you always for the great community and answering my questions over the last few days.

author: dock_boss
content: <@303389476284006402>  I'd try free code camp and w3 schools for js

author: dkdkdkdkdkdk
content: eth2.0 specs are all in Python so it would be useful to know too

author: pipermerriam
content: python is pretty common in the research space.  There's no one language that protocol development happens in.  Lots of researchers do proof-of-concept work in python.  There's a lot of golang as well due to go-ethereum having a large market share.  But there's no official language.  General programming competency is really the skill you need, which is unfortunately, not a very well defined thing.

author: pipermerriam
content: I personally learned most of the protocol by actually implementing it...  most of the specs have test vectors, and it feels really good when your code suddenly produces the "right" answer.

author: timbeiko
content: Before doing a CS degree, I used https://launchschool.com to learn to program. Not sure I would recommend it as a path to become a core developer, but it was useful to learn programming in general, which is a prerequisite

author: lightclient
content: if you have experience, i think a great approach is to find a university you like and go through the syllabus of some classes and follow the lessons (many of them also have projects online) - if you do a data structures/algorithms class, a networking class, and a operating systems class you'll have a really solid foundation

author: pipermerriam
content:
I'll be looking for how to continue "enabling" you to focus your effort on the protocol.  This could be continued "grant" style funding, helping you find a job on a team that's working on something interesting to you, or whatever it is that I can help with to keep you working with us.

If the program shows promise then we'll probably try to rope you into helping out with the next cohort.

author: spiralglide
content:
I'm curious what ideas for improvement people already have that have applied for the program. I listed out a couple in my application (privacy in transactions, off-chain communication, and on-chain scheduled contract invocations).

Just seems like right now is a good time to try to find people we'd be interested in working with should we get accepted (unless there's an intended stage for that pre-project but post-acceptance)

author: akh4880
content: Also interested in private transactions/private computations. Although I am not sure how to efficiently implement it or it is "fully" necessary, I am really interested in applications for Fully Homomorphic encryption. Maybe this is beyond Ethereum which is IMO very cool since everything is public, but being able to securely compute and run encrypted data is a very cool idea.
